title: The Nanjing Massacre
summary: A six-week period of large-scale killing, rape, and arson committed by Japanese military forces against the civilian population. The scale and brutality of the atrocities shocked the international community.
detailed_description: The Nanjing Massacre, also known as the Rape of Nanking, occurred between December 1937 and January 1938 when the Imperial Japanese Army captured the Chinese capital. During this six-week period, Japanese troops engaged in systematic mass killing, rape, and destruction. The fall of Nanjing marked a turning point in the Second Sino-Japanese War and became a symbol of Japanese military brutality.

impact.immediate_casualties: Estimated 200,000-350,000 deaths, including civilians and soldiers
impact.property_destruction: Approximately one-third of buildings destroyed or damaged
impact.sexual_violence: Systematic rape used as weapon of war targeting women and children
impact.psychological_trauma: Survivors and descendants afflicted with lasting trauma

historical_context: The Nanjing Massacre occurred at a critical moment in the Second Sino-Japanese War, following Japan's swift military victory in northern China. Scholars attribute the brutality partly to racial ideology, military culture, and dehumanization of the enemy.
recognition_timeline: January 1938: Six weeks of massacre ends
1985: Memorial established; Japan passes curriculum standards minimizing events
2014: Japan Education Ministry continues to downplay or deny certain aspects
Present: Ongoing disputes over historical interpretation and education
current_status: Memorial Hall established in Nanjing; International recognition; Significant historical and political disputes continue between China and Japan regarding the scale and characterization of events
references: Iris Chang, The Rape of Nanking: The Forgotten Holocaust of World War II
Joshua Fogel (ed.), The Nanjing Massacre in History and Historiography
Marjorie Dorn, Japan War Crimes Research Center
